statement: As someone who cares deeply about this country and our communities, I think the best way to increase trust in our elections is through transparency and accountability at every step. We should have stronger voter ID laws, cleaner voter rolls, and clear, publicly available audits of results so people can see for themselves that the process is fair. I also believe both parties and the media need to tone down the constant accusations and instead focus on explaining how the system works, so ordinary folks don’t feel like the game is rigged before it even starts.

To increase trust, we need strict voter ID laws, clean and regularly audited voter rolls, and strong protections against mail-in ballot abuse, with both parties allowed full, transparent observation of the process. Results should be reported clearly and quickly, with any irregularities publicly explained in plain language. If people can see that every legal vote is counted and illegal votes are stopped, confidence will grow again.

statement: At my age, having lived through quite a few election cycles here and back in Ireland, I’ve learned that trust comes from transparency and neighbors talking to neighbors, not from shouting on television. We should expand nonpartisan poll worker programs and invite more ordinary citizens, including retirees like me, to observe and help run elections, while clearly explaining voting procedures and security measures in plain language. I’d also like to see stronger protections against voter intimidation and disinformation, so people can vote without fear and with good, accurate information. If folks can see with their own eyes that the process is fair and well run, they’ll be far more likely to accept the results, win or lose.

statement: I think people would trust elections more if everything about them was easier to see and understand, like putting all the rules, security steps, and results in simple language online so anyone can check them. It would also help if schools taught us how voting and counting really work, and if both political parties agreed on fair rules ahead of time instead of arguing about cheating only when they lose.
